title: 111_s3055
content: The Act titled "Green Communities Act of 2009" is established for the purpose of promoting environmentally friendly practices. The Act finds that landscaping enhances economic value and sales appeal of real estate, improves neighborhood perceptions, reduces crime, and increases property values. It also states that well-landscaped areas attract more shoppers and increase property values. The Act aims to promote investment in greening projects, connect urban economic development with environmental initiatives, improve quality of life for city residents, and encourage public-private partnerships. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The curr_chunk defines a "community greening initiative" as a program that promotes economic development through environmental improvement, including park revitalization, landscaping, tree plantings, open space planning, education, green roof construction, stormwater infrastructure, and vacant lot management. The curr_chunk defines terms like "green roof" as vegetation over a waterproofing membrane, "green stormwater infrastructure" as natural water management systems, "nonprofit organization" as tax-exempt under IRS code, and "Secretary" as the Secretary of Commerce. Urban forestry is an integrated approach to planting, caring for, and managing trees in cities or neighborhoods to provide environmental and social benefits for residents. SEC. 4. GRANTS FOR COMMUNITY GREENING INITIATIVES. The Secretary may award grants to eligible municipalities for community greening initiatives, with a maximum grant amount of $2,000,000. Eligible municipalities must meet specific criteria outlined in the Public Works and Economic Development Act of 1965. Applicants must submit an application for the grant. Eligible municipalities must submit an application to the Secretary for a community greening initiative grant. The Secretary will select 80 municipalities that have successfully planned such initiatives. Grants cannot exceed 2 years to complete. Each eligible municipality receiving a grant for a community greening initiative must use the funds for that purpose. They must also provide non-Federal funds amounting to at least 50% of the grant awarded. A report assessing the initiative's implementation must be submitted by the assisting nonprofit organization within 60 days of completion. Technical assistance and training will be provided to municipalities as part of the community greening initiative grant requirements. The Secretary will award grants or contracts to 5 eligible nonprofit organizations for a 5-year period to provide technical assistance and training to municipalities receiving grants under section 4. Eligible nonprofit organizations must have experience in urban open space projects, land conservation, community work, forming partnerships, and urban ecology. The eligible nonprofit organizations awarded grants will provide technical assistance and training to municipalities for community greening initiatives, including developing, planning, and implementing projects, as well as conducting training workshops for municipal agencies and partners. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress within 90 days after the fiscal year ends, detailing the technical assistance and training provided for community greening initiatives. The report will outline actions taken to ensure that the assistance is tailored to the needs of municipalities receiving grants. SEC. 6. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Authorization of appropriations for the Act includes $30,000,000 for fiscal years 2010, 2013, and 2014, and $90,000,000 for fiscal years 2011 and 2012. Funds are reserved for community greening initiatives and technical assistance and training. For fiscal years 2011 and 2013, 28 percent of funds are allocated. Funds under this Act remain available until expended.
